title: Physical pendulums - hoop and small massive sphere

content.question: A physical pendulum is constructed from a hollow hoop, a small sphere, and a rod of negligible mass, as shown in the figure. The small sphere has mass <math alttext="5 uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and is attached to the top of the hoop, which has mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and radius <math alttext="R sub 0 equals 0.080 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>080</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math>. The rod has length <math alttext="the fraction R sub 0 over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> and connects the hoop-sphere system to a pivot about which the pendulum can rotate. What is the period of small-angle oscillations for the pendulum?
